pros: Friendly environment, flexible, great to work with
cons: Location can be tough depending on where you travel from.

pros: New leadership has finally settled in and is moving in such a positive direction for growth and investment in the community (of students AND staff!).
cons: Still some pay and staffing issues.

pros: The benefits at this company were great.
cons: No hybrid or work from home flexibility. Lower pay because benefits were great.

pros: Good medical and health benefits. Good work-life balance. In the summer you only have to work half a day on Friday which is lovely. The location is great too with nice beaches. The company has given me a cost of living raise every year which is great.
cons: Not a lot of teamwork. The culture could be more inclusive and positive.

review_title: Toxic environment and culture of fear
pros: Beach setting, good health insurance
cons: I worked there for 6 years and watched the place go downhill fast as new leadership took hold, albeit there were many cracks in the system to begin with. Expected to keep head down and mouth shut. College boasts DEI efforts that are entirely superficial while dismantling support that was in place for few students of color and from underserved backgrounds. Pay is also below industry standard, yet expectations remain for staff to work extra unpaid hours.

review_title: Supportive environment, respectful coworkers, beautiful campus
pros: I worked pretty independently, but the full-time staff were great at answering questions when I needed help. Otherwise I was kind of allowed to do my own thing.
cons: I wish I had been able to pick up more hours--I loved working there and unfortunately only worked weekends.

pros: Beautiful campus that is meticulously maintained. Buildings are all modern and clean. There is an effort made to develop community spirit.
cons: Changes seem to be constant. Restructuring has occurred twice in a year with in the same department. Management seems to be unsure of future direction.

pros: Very considerate boss to work for
cons: A tad boring to fax stuff

review_title: Great first place to work after college
pros: Nice people, beautiful campus, great professors
cons: Low pay, and parking is difficult

pros: Good place to work for me
cons: None that I am willing to say

pros: Fair pay, great benefits. Some really good people still work there.
cons: The rules are not the same for everyone. Favoritism is rampant. The old Endicott that was known and loved ... is no longer. Horrible management.

pros: Endicott College feels like a community where everyone collaborates and works hard to make students successful.
cons: There is a need for additional staff to better serve the community and our students.

review_title: Terrible pay, lack of support, toxic/racist leadership
pros: located directly across from beach
cons: Over worked, underpaid, lack of support, gaslighted by leadership day in and day out to do the work that no one else wanted to do while getting little to no work life balance or compensation for it

pros: Beautiful place to work, supportive staff community, incredible benefits. The days off make it barely necessary to use vacation time and you can get a Master’s for free. Overall, I felt very content working there.
cons: The administration pushes people to have PhD without providing the means to acquire, therefore limiting growth.

job_title: Director of Student Activities in Beverly, MA
pros: leadership development, engagement, advising, empowerment
cons: work life balance can be an issue.

pros: Endicott College hires well. I worked with a great team.
cons: I can't think of any; my experience there was wonderful.

pros: COMMUNITY, culture, students, vibrant, learning
cons: COVID-19, growth is limited, academia,

pros: great, great atmosphere and Morale
cons: to much work sometimes in the begining

review_title: Excellent Working Environment, Great Students, Awesome People!
pros:
+The students, staff, and fellow faculty members are awesome!
+The classrooms are well-equipped. 
+Great work-life balance.
+Online course webpage is easy to use as an instructor.
cons:
-Low pay, inconsistent enrollment in the satellite programs make it hard to guarantee a teaching position.
-The majority of faculty are part-time, which takes away from the student experience. 
-Allow more courses to run on a hybrid model, rather than either all face to face or all online. A mixture helps to promote the independence while also building the student/instructor relationship.

pros: I worked in the Van Loan department (adult, evening, and online students) which was small. I enjoyed my team. The campus is beautiful and being an employee gets you free entrance to a lot of events at the school as well as the gym.
cons: The job I interviewed for was very different than the job I actually ended up doing. The Van Loan school has less resources than the day school and is generally looked down on. The staff is older so being young puts you at a disadvantage. The small staff means you do 5 jobs. I worked a lot of evenings and weekends, but that was the position. I left after three months, but on good terms. It just wasn't the job I was looking for.

pros: I worked in EC Fine Arts Department for five years, with at least one class every semester. It was a great experience with intelligent, supportive and engaging colleagues. I was given the input and resources I needed to develop courses which I felt provided real value to the students. Beautiful campus.
cons: It would be nice if the department were bigger with a wider variety of students. A lot of them are in graphic design and interior design. Not sure how to crack that nut.

review_title: A great little place to work.
pros: Great colleagues, flexible coursework, ability to grow and develop academic coursework, great benefits, small and beautiful campus that is easy to navigate. While the small campus can create a bubble, there are some great students who maximize the intimacy of the campus to delve into their studies and get to know professors in order to push themselves academically.
cons: Administration has a short-term memory with institutional problems; "quick fixes" are usually a bandaid over larger issues (which admin does not want to tackle). More mentorship required for junior faculty. More support for faculty research necessary.

review_title: It would be great if they would hire me full time.
pros: This is a rapidly growing college on a beautiful campus. Administration and employees are dedicated to providing a solid learning experience for students.
cons: Like many institutions of higher education, the college is overly reliant on adjunct faculty. In addition, the rapid expansion of the campus sometimes leaves employees displaced, physically, or in terms of their career.

review_title: Nice Place, would recommend EC, although the pay is below average for the Boston area.
pros: Nice environment, dedicated faculty and staff, updated and new facilities. Attracts good students, generally positive vibe. Generally positive relationships between faculty and administration.
cons: Pay is below average for Boston-area colleges. Although athletics are prioritized, Endicott College is a Division 3 school, not Division 1. Students seem to be mostly from the white US northeastern suburbs.

job_title: Assistant Director of Student Activities in Beverly, MA
pros: There are myriad opportunities for experiential learning, which stems from the academic model of the college. Opportunities for growth can be sought out if the individual desires.
cons: Leadership style conflicts directly with the rate of physical growth the campus experiences. Change is not allowed to happen organically, but rather is directed by the top tier of administration.

review_title: Strong community at its core with spotty leadership
job_title: Executive Director of Marketing in Stoneham, MA
pros: The students are exceptional. They are truly passionate about their academic pursuits, career aspirations, and being active members of the community. The campus is beautiful with ocean views. Athletics is offered at both the varsity, club, and intramural levels. Varsity programs are mostly successful and attract quality student-athletes.
cons: Leadership struggles with transparency and authenticity with its staff. Community is often left in the dark on significant changes to campus structure, culture, and future.

pros:
- The Residence Life team can feel like a family 
- Provides valuable leadership experience and great friendships
cons: - Does not pay nearly enough compared to what other colleges and universities pay their Residence Life staff

review_title: Lack of Diversity/Respect for People of Color
pros: Beautiful campus right on the ocean
cons: Complete lack of diversity, and students of color expressed feelings of being unwelcome. It's the 800 lb elephant in the room. No one talks about it.

job_title: Web Content Writer/Editor in Beverly, MA
pros: Great people to work with. Relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Some tasks get repetitive. Not much room for promotion.

pros: Supportive staff. Great location. Easy commute. Career growth
cons: Majority of the benefits don't apply to adjuncts and part time faculty

pros: Great community to work in, beautiful campus
cons: Some decisions from admin were inconsistent.

pros: Work around my hours, friendly people
cons: Not very challenging, minimum wage and little hours

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Beverly, MA
pros: Great community, experienced faculty and staff
cons: Not a lot of turnover

pros: Great location.  Excellent educational institution.
cons: There are not great opportunities for advancement.
